content: The folder hierarchy in Thunderbird directly reflects the folder hierarchy in the filesystem within the profile folder. There is no mechanism to make a folder that's not within Local Folders in the filesystem to appear as if it was in the folder pane.
creator: DavidGG

content: Actually, I haven't tried, but a symbolic link might work.
creator: DavidGG

content:
This article explains how to move the location of mail folders:

http://kb.mozillazine.org/Moving_your_mail_storage_location_-_Thunderbird

Basically, you would copy your Local Folders folder from the profile to D, then set the Local Directory to that location.

There's also an add-on to define multiple Local Folders:

https://addons.thunderbird.net/en-us/thunderbird/addon/localfolder/

content:
Thunderbird has changed a bit since v38. You may want to check this:

https://support.mozilla.org/kb/getting-started-thunderbird-main-window-supernova

The 'Get Messages' button is that small icon to the left of the '+ New Message' button, and the option to add the column of total messages in the '···' menu to the right.
creator: DavidGG

content: Thank you. I see both now. However the icons are microscopic. The Get Messages icon blends into the background it's so small. Is there a way to make the icons larger?
creator: wdolson

content:
wdolson said
Thank you. I see both now. However the icons are microscopic. The Get Messages icon blends into the background it's so small. Is there a way to make the icons larger?

At least you can see them. And, if you can see them, you know where to click. When I first installed thunderbird, I thought there was a smudge on the screen. Go to View/Tool Bar/Customise Drag 'Get Messages' (and any other icon you want) onto the Tool Bar
creator: frisée

content:
There's a hidden setting that controls the resolution at which Thunderbird displays and sometimes has a wrong value for some reason.

Go to Settings > General, click Config Editor at the bottom, then type layout.css.dpi in the search box.

What value does it show? If not -1 (default), note the current value (in case you want to change it back), set it to the default -1, and see whether things look better. If the change makes things worse, just change the setting back to the value it had before.
creator: DavidGG

content: Other places to check that you didn't mention would be Address Book using Google Contacts and the possibility that you configured some other account to use that Gmail SMTP server, which is probably still available in Outgoing Server (SMTP) settings, at the bottom of the list of accounts in the Account Settings tab.
creator: DavidGG

content: It's an error message generated by the SMTP Server (outgoing) informing you either that you are sending above your quota of emails per hour or, perhaps more accurately, that such actions are not allowed as they are suspiciously like bulk spam sending.

content:
“Sending failed. Message couldn’t be sent because the connection to the outgoing server SMTP timed out. Try again.”

If you search for the string "the connection to the outgoing server SMTP timed out" in the top right search field, there will be numerous articles with information about how to resolve this issue.

The most common solution is that Anti-Virus software needs to be switched off from scanning emails.

If the solutions offered don't work, please reply to the post and it will be relisted as in need of a solution.
creator: frisée

content: The Junk Folder is part of the system default files in Thunderbird. However, you can tell TB to send Junk mail to whichever folder you want. Go to Hamburger icon (top right)/Account Settings/Junk Settings (left - for each account you have)/Change the settings under 'Destination and Retention'
creator: frisée

content: You would need to reset the password with your Email Provider. Thunderbird only uses the passwords that you supply to it. It's a shame that your HD has failed - it would have been possible to use it as an external HD and to use the profiles to install them on your new computer.
